publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 72.04

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and translation are based on .

Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).

seg.seg: (it attains the dwelling of the gods) through its flawless perfection. Therefore in my opinion, human skill is superior to all. 5. Prajñāvān [“the Wise”] speaks: There is no
other thing that does so much good to the world as wisdom, because ignorance
is the root of the spread of all bad things and all damages. Wisdom, however, cuts off the root of foolishness.
Like that there is a plant named Krośavatī, in whatever earth it takes root, from there one krośa
Wherever on earth it strikes root, from there on its wood grows on earth for krośas. (cf 7)
its stem will grow away far over the earth. The krośa-plant is five hundred fathoms in size. Having grown one krośa, it is cut down.
(Undestroyed) it produces a new sprout. From there it grows again one krośa, and undestroyed from there
one krośa it grows. Growing in this way it spreads up to 100 miles in the earth. || In the K.-tune: ||
Auf solche Art und Weise wachsend, verbreitet es sich bis zu 100 Meilen weit auf der Erde fort.
Growing in this manner, it spreads up to a hundred miles over the earth.
Even cut, even destroyed, the Krośavatī, with only a small piece left over, grows as much [as before].
Just so are the ignorant ones: even beaten, even nipped, as soon as they have the possibility, they spread in badness. 1.
On the mountain Himavant, however, there is a king [named] Vajramukha [“Diamond-mouth”]. Where this one bites it, the plant Krośavatī
Wherever he bites it through, the Krośavatī plant is ruined completely. (cf 7)
dies completely. Just so are the beings because of their ignorance.
In all bad things and in all damages they spread. Well, when the foolishness (Krośavatī is bitten through) by the wisdom Vajramukha
Well, when the foolishness Krośavatī is bitten through by the wisdom Vajramukha, at that moment the ruin of all harms is there, and the spread of all advantages. (cf 8)

p.note: The translation is largely based on 7-8, and .
The metre of the tune is 4x12, rhythm 4/4/4.

div.p: Edition5. Siegling's personal copy of p. 5.

list.item:
The translation is largely based on [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 7-8, and [[Carling, DThTA]].

b1f. The metre of the tune is 4x12, rhythm 4/4/4.

a1 yātluneyo sne nā_k_a_m\ : _t_amyo amok ñi _p_alskaṃ p_ukaṃ pruccamo wrasaśśi : 5 || prajñavāṃ t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ mā _t_a (–) a2 saṃ ālak wra_m\ ārkiśoṣṣi_s\ kāsu ypan_t\ na_ṣ\ kos ne knānmune kyalte āktsune pu_k\ o_m_as[k]e(–) a3 -s wramnāśśi pu_k\ kārya_p_aṃtwāśśi _s_atkāluneyaṃ tsmār nāṃtsu knānmune nu ākntsuneyi_s\ –(–) a4 -rṣnān_t\ _m_aṃt ne krośavati ñomā okar na_ṣ\ äntāṃ tkanā ne _s_a_m\ tsmār _k_arkñä_ṣ\ _t_m_aṣṣ aci kr[o](–) a5 – naṃ lo_k\ o_r\ oktsi_ṣ_ṣ-_aṃ _p_añ _k_an_t\ kaṣas kroś _m_aska_t_ar krośä\ okṣiṃñu_r_a_ṣ\ kotluneyaṃ yä_ṣ\ a6 – – –_ṣ\ nuna_k\ kom ya_t_a_r\ _t_m_aṣṣ aci nuna_k\ krośä\ oksi_ṣ\ nuna_k\ nmā kāko_r_a_ṣ\ – – b1 – –(–) krośä\ oksi_ṣ\ taṃne tiryā oksismāṃ okā_k\ _k_an_t\ kurtsru tkanaṃ lo_k _s_atkat_r_a || ku – – b2 – – s penu kākos penu krośavati : tsru kuc yärmaṃ lipos nuna_k\ npre_n_a_k\ oksi_ṣ\ : _t_amne_k\ – b3 -kntsā – kākoṣtuṣ pe pā_p_l_aṅkuṣ pe : tsru ke _k_alpo_ṣ\ n_una_k\ _s_atkaṃ_t_a_r\ o_m_askenaṃ : 1 || hi- b4 -mavan_t\ ṣulaṃ nu vacramukhe wäl na_ṣ\ äntā ne _s_a_m\ trāska_ṣ_aṃ sā_m\ krośavati o – b5 -_r\ _p_u_k_aṣ pu_k\ nkaluneyaṃ yä_ṣ\ _t_amne_k\ nṣaṃ ākntsuneyi_s\ cämpluneyā wrasañ pu_k\ o_m_ask[u] – b6 -yntwaṃ puk kārya_p_aṃtwaṃ śkaṃ _s_atkāluneyaṃ yä_ṣ\ äntā ne nu knānmuneṣiṃ vajramukhenyo ākntsune –

a1 ; yātluneyo , sne nākäm : #5c tämyo amok_(TA)|amok , ñi pälskaṃ ; p_ukaṃ pruccamo , wrasaśśi : 5 #5d || prajñavāṃ träṅkäṣ mā_(TA)|mā tä(preṃ) a2 saṃ ālak wram ārkiśoṣṣis kāsu ypant naṣ kos ne knānmune kyalte āktsune puk omäskenās|omäske(nā)|s a3 wramnāśśi puk kāryapäntwāśśi|kāryapäṃtwāśśi sätkāluneyaṃ tsmār nāṃtsu knānmune nu ākntsuneyis (tsmār kärṣnānt|kä)|rṣnānt a4 mäṃt ne krośavati ñomā okar naṣ äntāṃ tkanā ne säm tsmār kärkñäṣ tmäṣṣ aci kro(ś) a5 (tka)naṃ lok or_(TA)|or oktsiṣṣ-äṃ päñ känt kaṣas kroś mäskatär kroś okṣiṃñuräṣ kotluneyaṃ yäṣ a6 (tmā kākorä)ṣ nunak kom yatär tmäṣṣ aci nunak kroś oksiṣ nunak {t}mā kākoräṣ (tmäṣṣ aci) b1 (nunak) kroś oksiṣ taṃne tiryā oksismāṃ okāk känt kurtsru tkanaṃ lok sätkaträ || ku(swaṃ ||) b2 # (kärṣto)s penu ; kākos penu ; krośavati : #1a tsru kuc yärmaṃ ; lipos nunak ; {t}prenäk oksiṣ : #1b tämnek ākntsāñ|(ā)|kntsā(ñ) b3 ; kākoṣtuṣ pe ; pāpläṅkuṣ pe : #1c tsru ke kälpoṣ ; n_unak sätkantär|sätkaṃtär ; omäskenaṃ : 1 #1d || himavant|hi|mavant b4 ṣulaṃ nu vacramukhe wäl naṣ äntā ne säm trāskaṣäṃ sām krośavati okar|o(ka)|r b5 p_ukäṣ puk nkaluneyaṃ yäṣ tämnek {t}ṣaṃ ākntsuneyis cämpluneyā wrasañ puk omäskuneyntwaṃ|omäsku(ne)|yntwaṃ b6 puk kāryapäntwaṃ|kāryapäṃtwaṃ śkaṃ sätkāluneyaṃ yäṣ äntā ne nu knānmuneṣiṃ vajramukhenyo ākntsune(ṣiṃ)

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a4-5 Wherever on earth it strikes root, from there on its wood grows on earth for krośas. (cf [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 7) 258
b4-5 Wherever he bites it through, the Krośavatī plant is ruined completely. (cf [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 7) 650
b6-a2 Well, when the foolishness Krośavatī is bitten through by the wisdom Vajramukha, at that moment the ruin of all harms is there, and the spread of all advantages. (cf [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 8) 278


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
b1 Auf solche Art und Weise wachsend, verbreitet es sich bis zu 100 Meilen weit auf der Erde fort. 278


  • a4-b1: in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 104, there are some differences: (mā kākorä)ṣ and oksiṣ nunak mā kākoräṣ (both a6). (TI)
  • [[Carling, DThTA]]: has āk‹n›tsune in line a2 and kāryäpäṃtwāśśi in line a3 (TI)
  • b3: the translation runs as above in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 113-4, and “if they find only a small chance, they spread again in badness” ibid: 198 (TI)
  • beginning of a6: restoration (mā kākorä)ṣ and translation as above = [[Carling, DThTA]]: 104; in ibid: 206, the restoration reads (kāko)[tu]räṣ nunak kom yatär, translated as “after having split up, it [i.e., the plant] makes again a sprout”! - [[Peyrot 2011]]: 45 prefers the latter (TI)
  • towards the end of b2: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 220 has 〈tä〉prenäk (TI)
  • a2: [[TochSprR(A)]]: 5 correct āktsune to ākntsune. Since āktsune is attested two more times, I didn't alter the form in the transcription. (BK)
  • a4 (translation): äntāṃ is a relative determiner modifying and agreeing with tkaṃ (i.e. [ [ äntāṃfem.obl tkanfem.obl ] -ā ], so a more literal translation would be "whatever place it takes root." (BK)

a1 (it attains the dwelling of the gods) through its flawless perfection. Therefore in my opinion, human skill is superior to all. 5. Prajñāvān [“the Wise”] speaks: There is no a2 other thing that does so much good to the world as wisdom, because ignorance a3 is the root of the spread of all bad things and all damages. Wisdom, however, cuts off the root of foolishness. a4 Like that there is a plant named Krośavatī, in whatever earth it takes root, from there one krośa a5 its stem will grow away far over the earth. The krośa-plant is five hundred fathoms in size. Having grown one krośa, it is cut down. a6 (Undestroyed) it produces a new sprout. From there it grows again one krośa, and undestroyed from there b1 one krośa it grows. Growing in this way it spreads up to 100 miles in the earth. || In the K.-tune: || b2 Even cut, even destroyed, the Krośavatī, with only a small piece left over, grows as much [as before]. b3 Just so are the ignorant ones: even beaten, even nipped, as soon as they have the possibility, they spread in badness. 1. b4 On the mountain Himavant, however, there is a king [named] Vajramukha [“Diamond-mouth”]. Where this one bites it, the plant Krośavatī b5 dies completely. Just so are the beings because of their ignorance. b6 In all bad things and in all damages they spread. Well, when the foolishness (Krośavatī is bitten through) by the wisdom Vajramukha

div.p: • in <citedRange>104</citedRange></bibl>, there are some differences: <hi>(mā kākorä)ṣ</hi> and <hi>oksiṣ nunak mā kākoräṣ</hi> (both a6). (TI)</li><li><bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/></bibl>: has <hi>āk‹n›tsune</hi> in line <ref type="ms" target="__a2"/> and <hi>kāryäpäṃtwāśśi</hi> in line <ref type="ms" target="__a3"/> (TI)</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__b3:"/> the translation runs as above in <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>113-4</citedRange></bibl>, and “if they find only a small chance, they spread again in badness” ibid: 198 (TI)</li><li>beginning of <ref type="ms" target="__a6:"/> restoration <hi>(<b>mā</b> kākorä)ṣ</hi> and translation as above = <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>104</citedRange></bibl>; in ibid: 206, the restoration reads <hi>(kāko)[tu]räṣ nunak kom yatär</hi>, translated as “after having split up, it [i.e., the plant] makes again a sprout”! - <bibl><title corresp="ref:peyrot2011"/><citedRange>45</citedRange></bibl> prefers the latter (TI)</li><li>towards the end of <ref type="ms" target="__b2:"/> <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>220</citedRange></bibl> has <hi>〈tä〉prenäk</hi> (TI)</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__a2:"/><bibl><title corresp="ref:siegandsiegling1921"/><citedRange>5</citedRange></bibl> correct <hi>āktsune</hi> to <hi>ākntsune</hi>. Since <hi>āktsune</hi> is attested two more times, I didn't alter the form in the transcription. (BK)</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__a4"/> (translation): <hi>äntāṃ</hi> is a relative determiner modifying and agreeing with <hi>tkaṃ</hi> (i.e. [ [ äntāṃ<hi rend="subscript">fem.obl</hi> tkan<hi rend="subscript">fem.obl</hi> ] -ā ], so a more literal translation would be "whatever place it takes root." (BK)</li></ul></p></project_comment>
